# Problem 1 
## Problem 1.1a - create a variable and assign value of 35
```{r}
my_first_variable <- 35
```

## Problem 1.1b - divide 1st var by 9 and round to 3 sig figs
```{r}
my_second_variable <- signif(my_first_variable/9, 3)
```

## Problem 1.1c - print 2nd variable
```{r}
print(my_second_variable)
```

## Problem 1.1d - use floor() to round 2nd var to nearest int
```{r}
my_third_variable <- floor(my_second_variable)
```

## Problem 1.1e - print 3rd variable
```{r}
print(my_third_variable)
```

## Problem 1.2a - set seed for reproducability
```{r}
set.seed(8675309)
```

## Problem 1.2b - plot data from norm dist, mean 500, sd 10
```{r}
plot_data <- rnorm(20, mean=500, sd=10)
plot(plot_data,
     ylab = "Value",            # Y-axis label
     main = "Random Sample Norm Dist, Mean = 500 & SD = 10"  # Title
     )
```

# Problem 2

## Problem 2a
```{r}
library(ISwR)
extractedAge <- stroke$age
hist(extractedAge)
```

## Problem 2b
```{r}
mybreaks <- seq(from = 0, to = 100, length.out = 7)
hist(extractedAge,               #age data
     breaks = mybreaks           #Set breaks to len 7
     )
```

## Problem 2c
```{r}
hist(extractedAge,               #age data
     breaks = mybreaks,          #Set breaks to len 7
     main = "Age Histogram")     #Change title
```

## Problem 2d
```{r}
hist(extractedAge,               #age data
     breaks = mybreaks,          #Set breaks to len 7
     main = "Age Histogram",     #Change title
     xlab = "Age when stroke occured"
     )     
```

## Problem 2e
```{r}
hist(extractedAge,               #age data
     breaks = mybreaks,          #Set breaks to len 7
     main = "Age Histogram",     #Change title
     xlab = "Age when stroke occured",
     col = "blue"
     )     
```

## Problem 2f
```{r}
myColors <- c("aquamarine","azure","chartreuse","cyan","cornsilk","coral")
hist(extractedAge,               #age data
     breaks = mybreaks,          #Set breaks to len 7
     main = "Age Histogram",     #Change title
     xlab = "Age when stroke occured",
     col = myColors
     )     
```

## Problem 2g
```{r}
myColors <- seq(1,6)
hist(extractedAge,               #age data
     breaks = mybreaks,          #Set breaks to len 7
     main = "Age Histogram",     #Change title
     xlab = "Age when stroke occured",
     col = myColors
     )     
```

## Problem 2h
```{r}
hist(extractedAge,               #age data
     breaks = mybreaks,          #Set breaks to len 7
     main = "Age Histogram",     #Change title
     xlab = "Age when stroke occured",
     col = myColors,
     freq = FALSE
     )     
```



# Problem 3
## Problem3a
```{r}
library(ISwR)

extractedComa <- stroke$coma
ComaColumns <- extractedComa[c(759,760,761)]

cat("Print the values of the coma column in index positions 759, 760, and 761:")
print(ComaColumns) #print values in coma column in index 759, 760, and 761

cat("Print if the above values are NA:")
is.na(ComaColumns) #print if values in coma column in index 759, 760, and 761 are equal to NA. TRUE means value is NA. FALSE means not NA
cat("\nThe values in position 759 and 761 are not NA. The value in 780 is NA.")
```

## Problem3b
```{r}
table(stroke$coma,stroke$diab) #adding all combinations is 816, coma is rows and diab is columns
```
```{r}
length(stroke$coma) #length is 829 due to how NA values are used
```

## Problem3c
```{r}
myFirstTable <- table(stroke$coma,stroke$diab, useNA="always")
print(myFirstTable) #nopw the number of observations is 829, sum of all numbers and matches the length of stroke$coma
```

## Problem3d
```{r}
cat("Table with answers a little too exact:")
prop.table(myFirstTable) #answers too exact
cat("\nRound answers to 3 decimal places:")
round(prop.table(myFirstTable),3)
```

## Problem3e
```{r}
print("2nd argumenet as 1:")
round(prop.table(myFirstTable,1),3) #setting 2nd argument to 1, sum of each row proportion = 1

cat("\n2nd argumenet as 2:")
round(prop.table(myFirstTable,2),3) #setting 2nd argument to 2, sum of each column proportion = 1
```
